intro: Aphanostephus pulchellus, commonly known as the redstem sedgeland, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Poaceae family, commonly referred to as grasses, and is characterized by its tufted growth habit and slender, reddish stems. The plant produces small, inconspicuous flowers in spikelets, which are typical of grasses. It thrives in dry, open habitats such as grasslands and disturbed soils, often forming dense mats that help prevent erosion. Aphanostephus pulchellus is adapted to arid conditions and is often found in areas with low precipitation and well-drained soils.
